title: Research Methods and Scientific Writing in BEST
requirements: For students in MSc Biodiversity, Environmental Management, sustainability and Technology
description: This course aims to provide students with basic research methods, data analysis, writing and presentation skills in the field of Biodiversity, Environmental Management, Sustainability and Technology (BEST). Also, this course provides guidelines and educates students for conducting research responsibly and at a high ethical standard.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:Become acquainted with advanced skills necessary for conducting graduate research in the fields of biodiversity, environmental management, sustainability and related technologies, including laboratory management, information search, experimental design, presentation of research papers, writing of research proposal, thesis and scientific paper; Apply central concepts in research ethics to ensure integrity and ethical compliance in all research endeavors.
syllabus: - Orientation- Writing and presentation skills- Ethics- Research highlights- Case studies- Discussion

title: Techniques in Molecular Biology, Genomics and Bioinformatics
requirements: For students in MSc Biodiversity, Environmental Management, sustainability and Technology
description: This course provides a comprehensive exploration of key techniques and tools in molecular biology, genomics, and bioinformatics. Students will gain insights into fundamental methodologies such as DNA/RNA extraction, modification, and amplification, gene cloning, sequencing technologies, and CRISPR-based genome editing. The curriculum also delves into genomic data analysis, including transcriptomics, functional genomics, and epigenetics, alongside bioinformatics tools for sequence alignment, comparison, and functional annotation. Through engaging lectures and practical computational exercises, students will develop the skills necessary to analyze and interpret complex biological data, emphasizing the integration of molecular biology techniques with computational strategies to address biological challenges. Designed to build a robust theoretical foundation, this course equips students for advanced studies or careers in research, biotechnology, and related disciplines.
outcome: ● To understand basics of molecular biology;● To know fundamentals of genome and genomics;● To understand fundamentals and development of gene sequencing technology;● To understand basic sequencing analysis;● To gain practical experience in the frequently used tools of genomics
syllabus: Class 1: introduction to molecular biology techniquesClass 2: nucleic acid manipulation and amplificationClass 3: recombine DNA technologyClass 4: sequencing technologiesClass 5: genome editing technologiesClass 6: introduction to genomicsClass 7: chromatin and histoneClass 8: epigenome and epigeneticsClass 9: single-cell and spatial genomicsClass 10: sequence alignment and assemblyClass 11: transcriptomics and functional genomicsClass 12: presentation 1Class 13: presentation 2

title: Field Survey
requirements: For students in MSc Biodiversity, Environmental Management, sustainability and Technology
description: This course introduces basic fieldwork techniques and analytical methods in conducting field surveys. Students are required to conduct fieldwork in different habitats. Conventional and latest methods in ecological and environmental evaluation will also be introduced in this course.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:- demonstrate proficiency in ecological and field surveying techniques, including sample collection, data collection, data analysis, basic statistics, and data reporting.- analyze habitats and populations to understand their dynamics and interactions.- observe, record, and quantify ecological targets accurately using standard methodologies.- understand and apply concepts of experimental design and hypothesis testing in ecological research.- present and report findings and ideas effectively using charts, graphs, diagrams and tables.- integrate theory and practice through field exercises.- appreciate the nature through field trips and site visits and understand how the environment is closely related to us.
syllabus: - Basic fieldwork techniques and analytical methods in conducting field surveys- Conducting fieldwork in different habitats- Analysing habitats and populations- Using conventional and latest methods in ecological and environmental evaluation

title: Applied Ecology and Conservation
requirements: For students in MSc Biodiversity, Environmental Management, sustainability and Technology
description: This course introduces major concepts, daily-life examples, issues, technologies, and possible solutions in ecology and conservation. Topics will include modern techniques used in biodiversity estimation, functions of protected areas, wildlife conservation, habitat restoration, and conservation policies/laws.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:- understand key concepts in ecology and conservation;- identify important questions and key issues in modern ecology and conservation;- Apply scientific methods to issues relating to ecology and conservation;- apply the concepts of experimental designs and hypothesis testing;- find and collect information from research literature;- critically analyse information from primary research literature;- apply knowledge to real-world ecological and conservation issues and problems;- recognise the scientific basis of global and regional ecological, environmental, and conservation problems- appreciate the importance of biodiversity;- develop a scientific perspective on major global issues (e.g. biodiversity crisis, climate change) and their potential solutions
syllabus: - Applied Ecology- Biodiversity and Assessment- Conservation Biology- Endangered status of species

title: Environmental Impact Assessment
requirements: For students in MSc Biodiversity, Environmental Management, sustainability and Technology
description: This course introduces the concepts, as well as practices and skills that are widely used in evaluating environmental consequences resulting from anthropogenic activities. Students will be introduced to methods in assessment of environmental impact such as habitat and protected species surveys.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:- understand the theory and principles used in environmental impact assessment;- identify the methods used to assess environmental impact such as habitat and protected species surveys;- develop skills necessary of conducting effective environmental impact assessments;- explain the implications and challenges of EIA processes.
syllabus: - Hong Kong EIA system- Stakeholder engagement and public consultation- Basic principles and concepts of ecological, noise, water, air quality assessments- Case studies- Implications and challenges

title: Zoological Diversity and Pest Management
requirements: For students in MSc Biodiversity, Environmental Management, sustainability and Technology
description: This course presents the diversity of the major lineages of animals. The concepts and recent advance in animal phylogeny will be introduced and the enormous diversity of animals will be introduced through an evolutionary journey. We will discuss the major structural, anatomical and physiological characteristics in respect to the origin and adaptive radiation of animals. Second half of the course focus into the intricate relationship between zoological diversity and effective pest management strategies. Students will study the principles of zoological diversity conservation and its significance in sustainable pest control practices. Through a combination of theoretical knowledge and practical applications, students will gain insights into the cost and benefit of integrated pest management approaches, aiming to minimize environmental impact while effectively managing pest populations. By the end of this course, students will be equipped with the knowledge and skills needed to address pest challenges while promoting biodiversity conservation.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will1. Understand the diversity and evolutionary relationships among animals2. Understand the basic structure and function of different groups of invertebrates and vertebrates3. Understand the adaptation and limitations of different groups of animals in respect to their ecological role.4. Understand the economic, ecological, and sociological benefits for proper pest management5. Understand the principle and pros/cons for different pest control tactics6. Understand the main considerations (cost and benefits) for implementation of an effective pest control program
syllabus: Week 1: Broad classification of Animal Kingdom and Principles of Taxonomy Week 2: Molecular phylogenetic and new insights into animal evolution Week 3-4: Invertebrates: Arthropoda, Mollusc, Annelida and Echinodermata Week 5-6: Vertebrates: origin and adaptative radiation Week 7: Biological Control: Theory and Application Week 8: Introduction to common pests Week 9-11: Control Tactics: Principle, effectiveness and considerations Week 12: Integrated pest management: Policy and implementation Week 13: Challenges and monitoring of pest management
required_readings: Lecture handouts will be available on Blackboard. Furthermore, journal articles that relate to the recent development in the field will also be recommended during the course.

title: Literature Research in BEST
requirements: For students in MSc Biodiversity, Environmental Management, sustainability and Technology
description: Students, with the help of a supervisor, will identify a specific topic in the field of Biodiversity, Environmental Management, Sustainability and Technology (BEST) to perform literature research, and critically assess the scientific basis of the conclusions drawn. Students will discuss regularly with the supervisor and summarize the research findings in an oral presentation and a review paper.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:- demonstrate in-depth knowledge of the scientific method and research management principles.- develop competencies in finding, reading, and critically evaluating relevant scientific literature.- acquire skills in information searching, scientific writing and oral communication.- master generic skills such as critical thinking and lifelong learning techniques.- apply the basic statistical concepts and perform statistical analysis of biological data.- recognize the importance of academic honesty.
syllabus: - Start a Scientific Project Using ‘Scientific Method’- How to Write a Scientific Document- Scientific Conduct and Ethical Issues- Basic Statistics for Handling Experimental Data

title: Research Project on BEST
requirements:
For students in MSc Biodiversity, Environmental Management, sustainability and Technology
Pre-requisite: BEST5300 and BEST5380
description: In this course, students will acquire hands-on experience of performing a research project on a current topic in biodiversity, conservation, or environmental management under the supervision of a teaching staff. Students will be required to analyse the data, and summarise them in the format suitable for an international peer-reviewed academic journal.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:- demonstrate in-depth knowledge and skills in scientific methods and research processes;- develop competencies in finding, reading, and critically evaluating relevant scientific literatures;- execute experiments and analyse data carefully;- perform statistical analyses of data with good interpretations and discussion;- master generic skills such as critical thinking and lifelong learning techniques;- understand the importance of academic honesty.
syllabus: - Introduction for research-type M.Sc. Project- Rules and Safety in research labs- Conduct a research project on a current topic in biodiversity, conservation, or environmental management under the supervision
